EV Hub

A Distributed Web System for Electric Vehicle Analysis

MSc Computing Science – Project Documentation

Abstract

This project presents EV Hub, a distributed web-based system designed to analyze and compare electric vehicles using a decoupled architecture composed of a Flask-based REST API and a Django-based web interface. The system enables users to explore electric vehicle specifications, evaluate range feasibility based on travel distance, and perform side-by-side comparisons of vehicles. The project demonstrates modular design principles, scalability, and practical relevance to modern electric mobility challenges.

1. Introduction

The global transition toward electric vehicles (EVs) has introduced new challenges related to battery capacity, driving range, and consumer decision-making. While EV adoption continues to grow, potential users often experience uncertainty regarding whether a particular vehicle can meet their daily or long-distance travel requirements.

Existing vehicle comparison platforms typically present static specifications without evaluating range feasibility in relation to user-defined travel distances. This limitation motivates the development of EV Hub, a system that combines vehicle data with dynamic range analysis.

2. Problem Statement

Consumers lack accessible and interactive tools that integrate electric vehicle specifications with real-time range feasibility analysis. Most existing platforms provide static data without assessing whether a selected vehicle can satisfy a user's specific travel needs, contributing to range anxiety and suboptimal purchasing decisions.

3. Project Objectives

  • Design a modular system using a decoupled API-based architecture
  • Provide dynamic electric vehicle range feasibility analysis
  • Enable side-by-side comparison of electric vehicles
  • Ensure scalability and maintainability of the system

4. System Architecture

EV Hub follows a distributed client-server architecture with a clear separation of concerns between data processing and presentation layers.

  • Flask API: Handles vehicle data retrieval and range calculations
  • Django UI: Manages user interaction and data presentation
  • Communication: RESTful HTTP requests over localhost
Browser
   ↓
Django Web Interface (Port 8000)
   ↓
Flask REST API (Port 5000)

5. Technologies Used

  • Python 3.13
  • Django 6.0
  • Flask
  • Bootstrap 5
  • Chart.js
  • RESTful APIs

Django was selected for its robust templating and routing capabilities, while Flask was chosen for its lightweight API design. This combination allows independent scaling and future integration with external services.

6. Implementation Details

6.1 Data Retrieval

The Django application retrieves vehicle data by issuing HTTP requests to the Flask API, which responds with JSON-formatted data.

6.2 Range Feasibility Analysis

if trip_km <= vehicle_range:
    result = "Trip possible"
else:
    result = "Charging required"

This logic enables immediate feedback regarding whether a selected electric vehicle can complete a specified journey without recharging.

7. Results and Evaluation

The system successfully integrates a Flask API with a Django-based frontend to deliver real-time vehicle data and range analysis. Users can explore vehicle listings, compare two vehicles, and evaluate trip feasibility with minimal latency.

8. Limitations

  • Static dataset of electric vehicles
  • No real-time traffic or weather data integration
  • Localhost-based deployment

9. Future Work

  • Integration with real-world charging station APIs
  • Machine learning-based range prediction
  • User accounts and personalized recommendations
  • Cloud-based deployment and scalability

10. Conclusion

EV Hub demonstrates the feasibility of a modular, scalable web-based system for electric vehicle analysis. The project highlights the benefits of separating data processing and presentation layers while addressing practical challenges in electric vehicle adoption.
